direction.raw_text: Responses are mixed. Some cheer, some are undecided. Until the new band starts playing, "Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Old Oak Tree." And EVERYONE RUSHES for the exit, following Ted.

dialogue.raw_text: I bet St. Tropez in July would be paradise. For a honeymoon.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oops, sorry. Warning: You've got lipstick on your teeth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wow...you clean up nice. JULIE Put your eyeballs back in your head, William Randolph. I'm on assignment. A girl has to fit in.

dialogue.raw_text: Teddy, I thought we were having a moment here. TED Of course we were.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I apologize for interrupting the festivities, but I have some good news. I've been reviewing the rules and regulations set forth by the superintendent of schools. And it seems quite clear... (reading from manual) "Minors may not be accompanied to school functions by adults unless they are their parents or legal guardians."

dialogue.raw_text: So long, ladies. Prom's over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Honestly, Merk. It's like you were never seventeen and the head of a media empire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rules are rules.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, it's our only senior prom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Deaf ears, Mr. Nelson. I answer to a higher power.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out! Now!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's your price, Merk? How much will it cost to make you go bye bye?

dialogue.raw_text: You're crossing the line, Mr. Nelson.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A statue in front of city hall, dedicated to Principal Dick Merkin?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm warning you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A new pediatric wing at the hospital? A presidential campaign? Name it. Anything.

dialogue.raw_text: That's it! You're out of here!

dialogue.raw_text: Good-bye, Mr. Nelson.  Have a pleasant evening.

dialogue.raw_text: Ted! Do something!

dialogue.raw_text: (restrained) What do you want me to do?

dialogue.raw_text: This is humiliating. We're being ejected from a prom!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hang in there, I'll think of something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess...I don't know...I guess we should leave if we're not wanted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hear you, bro. We're Angus men in a ground round town.

dialogue.raw_text: This is what I get for playing den mother in "Romper Room." Take me to the airport, Charlie!

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you just hitch a ride on the horse you rode in on?

dialogue.raw_text: (calling after her) Don't forget your broom!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I loved her.

dialogue.raw_text: Chicks are like buses. If you miss one, don't sweat it. There's another coming 'round the corner.

dialogue.raw_text: (whispering to Ted) Take your pick. They're IDENTICAL.

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody, listen up! This prom sucks!  Let's party at my place!

direction.raw_text: A muzak version of "Tie a Yellow Ribbon Round the Old Oak Tree," continues.  A PIZZA DELIVERY GUY watches the numbers rise to the penthouse.  Suddenly the doors open to reveal...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All four penthouse suites have been rented by Ted.  It's party central. Very wild.  Quickly growing out of control. Kids dance, play drinking games, Spin the Bottle, and generally trash the place. The pizza delivery guy wheels a dolly with a huge stack of pizzas into the party, only to be attacked by the prom-goers like starving beasts. Grabbing the pizzas.  Devouring them hungrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted, Charlie, the Taylor Triplets and several buddies lounge around, drunkenly watching THE HOME SHOPPING CHANNEL on Ted's big screen TV.  A tacky CERAMIC GNOME rotates on the screen. Ted swigs Dom Perignon straight from the bottle. He shouts orders into his cell phone...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted looks up as the elevator doors open.  Principal Merkin has arrived. Ted confronts him...
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hell yes, all hundred and seventeen of 'em!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, leave one. Somebody's grandmother might want one.

dialogue.raw_text: And while you're at it, I'll take ten dozen of those puppies with the springy heads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I love those springy head puppies! CORRIDOR - MOMENTS LATER
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You kicked us off your turf, Merk. Don't rain on our parade.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Nelson, you disappoint me. First you break our school board rules. Then you break the law.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What law, Merk? Having fun? Letting down our hair on prom night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our state has a zero tolerance policy for underage drinking. TED You called the cops on us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alcohol does horrible things to a developing young mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Drunken teenagers pour out of the building.  Dashing for their cars and limos.  Ted's among them.  Suddenly he's cut off by a Harley that stops right in front of him.  It's Julie.  Still in her purple strapless prom dress. With a black motorcycle jacket over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted jumps on, wrapping his arms around her waist. Julie takes off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Need a lift?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Julie maneuvers the nighttime streets of Xenia, taking off down a country road.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) To the best hiding place in the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Now we understand. Julie's family comes from major bucks. The yard is massive. And resting in a sprawling oak tree is the best hiding place in the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cozy oasis. Books everywhere.  A whole series of flashlights hang upside down like lanterns. Giving the tree house a warm glow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Julie's eyes narrow. She should have known.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Julie groans.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can't believe your dad built this for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't. He had it built.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whatever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not "whatever."  It's two different things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He cared enough to want you to have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He phoned it in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I doubt it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now it makes sense, the whole neo Bohemian, down with hypocrisy, fight the power crap. You're a poor little rich girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The ozone must be fully depleted on Planet Ted.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think my dad would have been like that if I knew him? You think he would have bought me a stadium, instead of teaching me how to play ball? JULIE Your dad taught you everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A father is nothing but sperm, Ted. It takes a real man to be a dad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all so complicated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's incredibly simple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I feel like I'm being drawn and quartered. Like every part of me is being pushed and pulled and tugged in a different direction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Eventually you'll let go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you'll see who's really holding on to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're amazing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even when you infuriate me, I still want to kiss you. JULIE But you never do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we were a team, we could do anything. I mean, anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cut to the chase, William Randolph. Your audience is way ahead of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In a word: MERK. EXPOSED.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's two words. And I'm out of the "exposed" business, remember? I need to graduate. Besides, Merk's a boy scout.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's gotta be something. We have to dig deeper. JULIE You forget, I dislike YOU at least as much as him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He shut down your paper!  You're stuck writing articles about swap meets and raffles and PTA brunches!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A good journalist can take lemons and make lemonade. I'm honing my craft.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then you won't mind covering that watermelon seed spitting contest next week...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OLD FOLK'S HOME - NIGHT Dressed in a old fashioned barber costume, complete with a handle bar mustache, Principal Merkin sings as part of a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The senior citizens clap enthusiastically. Ted and Julie peek through a crack in the doorway. Disappointment on their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Principal Merkin pours soup into the bowl of a shabbily dressed HOMELESS MAN. Julie shoots Ted an "I told you so" look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Principal Merkin supervises a crew of kindergarten CHILDREN, cleaning up the roadside litter. Julie and Ted watch from...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See what I mean. He's squeaky clean. He makes Gandhi look like a war monger. Ted steels himself. Somehow, they'll get him.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: A BRIDGE ABOVE THE HIGHWAY JULIE

direction.raw_text: In the golden light of sunset, MOLLY, a stunning "Xenia Girl," stands on the stairs that curve up around a huge water tower that overlooks the city.  Her loose spring dress billows in the wind. Held on by only one button. Exposing in quick glimpses that she isn't wearing a bra. An ASSISTANT holds a portable strobe, attached to a reflector.  Charlie shoots with his Nikon.  Motor drive whirling. TED I have a great idea.  Let's lose the last button. Molly grins. Then unbuttons. We hear a round of "oohs" from below.  Ted glances down, where... Hundreds of binoculars, cameras, and camcorders are poised on the scene.  Men of all ages are milling around, gawking, focusing their long lenses.  Women are conspicuously absent. Except for the gaggle of hardcore FEMINISTS with their placards, denouncing "Heaven." One Feminist approaches the Mayor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Feminist tries to respond, but a helicopter swoops overhead, drowning out her words. The helicopter rises to the level of the photo shoot where the door slides open.  And just when we think it must have been hired by some hard core fans who wanted a closer look, we find Principal Merkin frowning as he barks through a bullhorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Molly flashes him. Principal Merkin averts his eyes.  Missing the sight of Molly's dress being blown off her body by the chopper's prop wash.  The spectators below APPLAUD.  They watch in amazement as her dress floats down to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Molly gets the idea.  She poses provocatively towards Principal Merkin, who suddenly realizes he's in a compromising position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Molly pulls off her panties and flings them at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The city tower belongs to the city, not to some pornographer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The library also belongs to the city.  And guess what?  It's going to have a new Ted Nelson wing with three thousand children's books.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You should be ashamed, young lady! Your body is a sacred temple!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Young lady, I will pray for god's mercy upon your soul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bother, Merk! I'm already going to "Heaven!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Charlie) Get them together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eyes lighting up) Brilliant!  Molly, give me all you've got.  For Merk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop that, stop that this instant!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy chortles, his image glowing on a large flat screen monitor that hangs on the wall.  Ted leans back in his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy grins proudly at Ted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted knows it's not true. He looks guilty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy forces a laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted smiles at the appealing offer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that, he's gone. The room is completely silent. And Ted is completely alone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I never saw anybody turn so many shades of red.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't wait to see the pictures.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was incredible. The light, the crowd, everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Such enthusiasm. Have I told you lately how proud I am of you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seriously? I'm doing all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're taking this bull of an empire by the horns, but you're still keeping your small town values. You're not letting all this "stuff" spoil you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I owe it all to you. Without your help I'd be lost.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish I knew you years ago, when my brother was alive. I wish he never gave you up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, well, like my Grandpa used to say...you can't change your Christmas past, but you sure can exchange your Christmas presents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you come to town this weekend? We could play some golf, chase some skirts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd love to, but I really need to crack the books.  Final exams are coming up and I've been slacking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're right. I should work, too. Our first issue together is almost ready to print.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Uncle Billy. Thanks for everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a great kid. Don't you forget it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: the doorbell CHIMES.

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: James, what are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can call me Jimmy again. Sheryl Petersen said James sounds too pretentious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sheryl Petersen is, what, nine years old, what does she know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She knew exactly where you were staying, which you neglected to tell me, your own brother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's really late...do your parents know where you are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom and Dad think I'm tucked safely in bed and that's all they need to know. Will this discussion be continuing in the hallway, or somewhere slightly more inviting?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jimmy whips out a piece of paper from his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted signs. Jimmy squirrels away the paper, excitedly. Starts to zip up his wind breaker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ouch. For the first time, that really smarts. TED He was my Grandfather, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted's stunned. Talk about tough love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly the phone rings. Ted sheepishly explains...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Impressive. This is bigger than our whole house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Most places are, Jimmy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They say money can't buy happiness but this is a reasonably good facsimile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, what brings you here at his hour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My new bike.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I came to ask permission to take custody of your room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My room?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better view, more spacious, new carpet. It's a no-brainer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not up to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mom and Dad said it's yours. They seem to think you're coming home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can have it, then. I'm not going back there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you could just sign right there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want it in writing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a formality.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's it? I mean, you don't want to order room service or anything? We could play games and watch movies and stuff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you kidding? Mom and Dad discover I'm gone and I'll be doing hard time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are they okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aside from the fact that Mom's eyes are nearly swollen shut from crying and Dad spends all his time under the car trying to fix stuff that isn't broken, things couldn't be better.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I miss them, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't come back. That is, you can, but your things will be in the room you currently think of as mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a peach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Funny you should say that. My Grandfather was a peach farmer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I meant biologically.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a crappy thing to say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look Ted. I'm cool with everything. You've long been dissatisfied with our mediocre little town. You've always had an itch for the good life. I'm happy for you. This couldn't happen to a nicer guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But just for the record, my Mom is a kick-ass schoolteacher and my Dad is the best damn auto mechanic this side of the Himalayas. You seem to have forgotten they opened Nelson's
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Market so they could build something permanent, a legacy, for us. Their kids.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't forget.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You ever look down on them again and call them "grocers" like it's a dirty word, and you'll be sucking your filet mignon through a straw for six to eight weeks. Got it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Loud and clear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's probably my office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Well? Where the hell are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's on the move?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I got an anonymous tip and an address in Cincinnati.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - LIVING ROOM - THAT MOMENT Ted hangs up the phone.  Looks around.  Jimmy's gone. But his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is left behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not much of a place. A middle-aged TORCH SINGER croons "MY ROMANCE."  Ted and Julie find their way to corner table. Keeping an eye out for Principal Merkin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their heads are very close together. A conspiratorial tete-a tete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At that moment, the TORCH SINGER begins crooning "PEOPLE."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted leans even closer. Looking into her eyes. Using his voice. Being as aurally seductive as he can.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ted moves closer.  Julie doesn't move away.  The SINGER seems to be performing just for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just as Ted and Julie are about to kiss, Julie's eyes widen. She grabs Ted's hand. Simultaneously, they turn towards THE SINGER...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's the Mother Lode!  That's not just any middle-aged torch singer. That's Principal Merkin.  Dressed in drag as Barbra Streisand. And doing a mighty fine job of it. Ted pulls out his camera and fires away. Blinded by the stage lights, Principal Merkin sings and vogues glamorously. He has no idea his secret is out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. This place seems pretty tame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You expected whips, chains, Merk being cattle-prodded by some dominatrix in a leather hood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least it's not another 4-H meeting or a Big Brother barbecue.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Amen to that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at us. It's one o'clock in the morning, on a school night. We're in a smoky nightclub, hoping to catch our principal with some big city tart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm trembling with excitement. TED That has more to do with your proximity to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (playing along) My desire betrays me, like goosebumps on my flesh. TED I have a bit of a goosebump fetish. Not many people know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I figured you for more of a hairy armpit guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shoes, if you want to know the truth. Shoes are my thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wearing them?  Or humping them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My fantasy is a totally naked woman, wearing nothing but a Timex and suede clogs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's refreshingly deviant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very aural.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sounds, voices, music, humming. All of it can turn me on, or off, like a switch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (feigning a deep voice) I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had a Portuguese boyfriend who could read the phone book and melt me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (jealous) A Portuguese boyfriend. Sounds very "Cosmo." JULIE You live and learn. I realized the most important thing to me, above all, is trust.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turned out to be a scoundrel, eh? I saw that one coming.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You lose trust in someone and it's over, done, gone, forever.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you trust me, Julie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not a chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Trust is something you earn, over time. You don't just inherit it overnight like a gazillion dollar empire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to trust me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe someday.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Julie, I'll tell you something that is the god's honest truth. I've seen a lot of really beautiful girls. I mean a lot. But none of them make me feel like you do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's hard to believe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But absolutely true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) ..."A feeling deep in your soul/Says you were half, now you're whole..."
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: & TED OH. MY. GOD.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ted and Julie rush down the street in the rain, giggling, totally euphoric. They stop to catch their breath. Their clothes are drenched, but they couldn't care less. In no time they've got their arms wrapped around one another, kissing and laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Julie sobers, pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Julie eyes him skeptically.

dialogue.raw_text: We just found the ULTIMATE centerfold for "The Girls of Xenia!"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to be honest with you, Ted. I really despise "The Girls of Xenia."

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) ...where he married all three of the identical Taylor Triplets. Let's just say, they've been very busy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) And even Uncle Billy landed on his feet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy wears a phone headset. He seems to be swimming in a sea of "Time-Life" style operators.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...with a two year subscription to "Heaven," you get a free underwater calculator.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And now if you'll excuse me, I think I'll get back to being the coxswain on the ship of life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ted and Julie sail off into, what else but a GLORIOUS SUNSET.
direction.name: direction
